name: Eochaid Airem

attributes.attribute: only way to populate the globe
describe a time of world creation

sources: Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: Eochaid Airem was the husband of Étain, the queen of Tara, who is the subject of Ireland’s most beautiful love story. Eochaid wished to become the king of Tara and, after proving his worthiness through successful combats, he scheduled his Inauguration. However, the people of Ireland refused to acknowledge him as king without a queen to represent the Sovereignty of the land. Eochaid then embarked on a journey to find the most beautiful woman in Ireland and found her in Étain who, unbeknownst to her, was the reincarnated lover of the Fairy king Midir. Étain had forgotten her identity due to being cursed by a jealous rival in previous incarnations. She willingly went to Tara to become Eochaid’s wife, but Midir had not forgotten about her. Midir proposed a wager to Eochaid and won Étain back, taking her to his great palace under the hill at Brí Léith. Before leaving Tara, Étain was pregnant and gave birth to a daughter whom Eochaid unknowingly married (see Ésa). From this incestuous union, their daughter, Mess Bua Challa, became the mother of king Conaire. Some have argued that incest motifs, such as those present in this myth, may hide myths of origin, as incest would have been necessary in the beginning of time to populate the world. Thus, this complex myth may describe a time of world creation.
